content:
Sure, here are some more examples of provocative questions from the Spark Selling methodology that I haven't provided yet:

1. "What's the real reason you're not getting the buy-in you need from your stakeholders?"
2. "What's the real obstacle preventing you from scaling your business?"
3. "What's the real bottleneck that's holding your team back?"
4. "What's the real cost of not keeping up with industry developments?"
5. "What's the real impact on your bottom line if you don't improve your processes?"
6. "What's the real opportunity for growth if you improve this area of your business?"
7. "What's the real reason you're not seeing the return on investment you expected?"
8. "What's the real reason you're not meeting your sales targets?"
9. "What's the real reason you're not retaining your customers?"
10. "What's the real reason you're not seeing the level of productivity you need from your team?"

These questions are designed to help the salesperson understand the customer's true needs, pain points and objectives, and to provide solutions that align with those needs. They are also meant to help the customer see the potential consequences of not addressing the problem or opportunity and to consider the potential benefits of taking action.
